instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWR_GOOD: What is ALL_SYS_PWR_GOOD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD. When you see ALL_SYS_PWR_GOOD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No chime, no image, no light if USB mouse plugged
threads.message:
Hi,
I'm on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that does not chime. There is no image on screen, and no light if USB Mouse plugged. Fans are spinning.
The board is able to charge the battery, and remains powered on if i unplug the charger or the battery. This part of the circuitry seems working.
I get the orange light on the charger, until the battery is fully charged.

I measured 0.92V on <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and 3.32V on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWR_GOOD</SIGNAL>.
Did a few random check here and there; 
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 12.52V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 12.54V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 1.79V

The heatsink is warm; <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> is warm (circa 60°C), and the coils L7510, L7520, L7550 and L7630 are warm too, (70°C)

I found these posts: [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-chime.3779/[/URL] and [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-no-chime-no-display.32104/[/URL] but original author didnt mention whether they found the cause.

There are no sign of liquid damage. Any clue ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No chime, no image, no light if USB mouse plugged
threads.message:
Did you check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and traces?
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?
